Author: rjurney
Content: People are copying this model without understanding it.  Transparency is needed to understand it.

Author: jamii
Content:
During my maths BA I took:

Foundation of computer science

Data structures and algorithms (SML)

Software engineering (Java)

Operating systems (C)

Numerical algorithms (C++)

as well as yearly catam projects: http://www.maths.cam.ac.uk/undergrad/catam/

There were also optional classes in bioinformatics and computational statistics and a number of lecturers encouraged the use of programming in solving weekly problem sheets.

I would estimate at least a third of my year-group were fairly competent programmers come graduation.

Author: mdemare
Content:
Mostly good advice, but the 10,000-hours-until-you're-an-expert meme bothers me. First, not everything is equally difficult. Playing the violin is harder than knitting.

Also, being an expert programmer suggests that you've levelled out, that you've reached a permanent high plateau. There is no plateau. It's a slope all the way to infinity.

If you find you've reached a plateau, shift gears and change to a more abstract programming language.

I'm at 30,000 hours, and I'm not an expert programmer. I'm still learning every day, and I like it!

Author: bumblebird
Content: Who cares? really. Lets not give Techcrunch so much attention for some vaporware.

Author: bumblebird
Content:
What is 'wave the framework'? We've had XMPP for 10 years. And it still hasn't really taken off.

Frameworks are pretty useless unless you have a killer app built on it.
